paragraphs.text:
# INSTALLING PYTHON

***Go to Python.org and download and install the latest version of Python 3.x; If You are using macOS or a Gnu/Linux distro there is a very good chance that Python 3.x is already insatlled.***

![Python](http://localhost:8088/images/download_python3.png)

msg.data:
INSTALLING PYTHON

Go to Python.org and download and install the latest version of Python 3.x; If You are using macOS or a Gnu/Linux distro there is a very good chance that Python 3.x is already insatlled.

paragraphs.text:
# STARTING REPL

***You can start Python REPL by typing***

```Bash
python3
```

***in the Windows Cmd or Unix Shell.***


![Python REPL](http://localhost:8088/images/repl.png)

msg.data:
STARTING REPL

You can start Python REPL by typing

python3

in the Windows Cmd or Unix Shell.

paragraphs.text:
# OTHER WORK ENVIRONMENTS FOR PYTHON

* ***Spyder*** (https://pythonhosted.org/spyder/)
* ***Jupyter*** (http://jupyter.org)
* ***Anaconda*** (https://www.anaconda.com/download/)
* ***PyCharm*** (https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/download/)
* ***GNU Emacs*** (https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/)
* ***Others*** (https://wiki.python.org/moin/IntegratedDevelopmentEnvironments)
* ***Apache Zepplin*** (https://zeppelin.apache.org)

paragraphs.text:
# SET UP A PYTHON VIRTUAL ENVIRONMENT!

***In many cases you need to have more than one version of Python installed(e.g. Python 3.4 besides Python 3.6); In these situations you can set up a Python virtual environment or virtualenv to install a complete Python a Python environment localy on your computer without breaking anything.***

***To create a python virtual environment run this command inside Cmd or Shell.***

```Bash

virtualenv -p python3 VENV # VENV is the virtual environment's directory

```

***Run this command inside the directory that you have created the virtual environment to activate it.***


```Bash
# POSIX VERSION
source VENV/bin/activate
```

```Bash
# WINDOWS VERSION
{PATH TO}ENV\Scripts\activate
```

***To deactivate the virtual environment use following command:***

```Bash
# POSIX AND WINDOWS VERSION ARE THE SAME!
deactivate
```

![Python Virtual Environment](http://localhost:8088/images/virtualenv.png)

msg.data:
SET UP A PYTHON VIRTUAL ENVIRONMENT!

In many cases you need to have more than one version of Python installed(e.g. Python 3.4 besides Python 3.6); In these situations you can set up a Python virtual environment or virtualenv to install a complete Python a Python environment localy on your computer without breaking anything.

To create a python virtual environment run this command inside Cmd or Shell.


virtualenv -p python3 VENV # VENV is the virtual environment's directory

Run this command inside the directory that you have created the virtual environment to activate it.

# POSIX VERSION
source VENV/bin/activate

# WINDOWS VERSION
{PATH TO}ENV\Scripts\activate

To deactivate the virtual environment use following command:

# POSIX AND WINDOWS VERSION ARE THE SAME!
deactivate

paragraphs.text:
# EASY_INSTALL & PIP

***One of main powers of Python programming language is that it comes with batteries included. You can install packages easily either by 'easy_install' or 'pip' tools.
easy_insatll is pre-bundled with Python as a helper script/command. You need to install pip separately.***

***For example to install pip as a package you can use this command:***

```Bash
easy_install -U pip
```

***In general I suggest you use pip, It's more advanced and high-level than easy_install.***

msg.data:
EASY_INSTALL & PIP

One of main powers of Python programming language is that it comes with batteries included. You can install packages easily either by ‘easy_install’ or ‘pip’ tools.
easy_insatll is pre-bundled with Python as a helper script/command. You need to install pip separately.

For example to install pip as a package you can use this command:

easy_install -U pip

In general I suggest you use pip, It’s more advanced and high-level than easy_install.

paragraphs.text:
# INSTALLING THE PACKAGES WE NEED IN THIS COURSE USING PIP

***Create a text file and put each package name(and its version number preceded with a '==') on a line separated by newline character('\n'); Usually this file is called 'requirements.txt':***

![Python](http://localhost:8088/images/requirements.txt.png)


```Bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

msg.data:
INSTALLING THE PACKAGES WE NEED IN THIS COURSE USING PIP

Create a text file and put each package name(and its version number preceded with a ‘==’) on a line separated by newline character(‘\n’); Usually this file is called ‘requirements.txt’:

pip install -r requirements.txt

paragraphs.text:
# USING A PYTHON DATA ANALYSIS SUITE WITH A GUI!

***Orange3(http://orange.biolab.si/) is a nice opensource dataflow programming environment and library for working with data(needs Python 3.5 and above to work). You can install it using this command:***


```Bash
pip3 install -U orange3
```

***Alternatively you could clone its source tree from Github.com and install it manually from https://github.com/biolab/orange3 .***

***To start using Orange3 run the following command in your terminal emulator or cmd:***

```Bash
orange-canvas
# or this command
python3 -m Orange.canvas
```

![Orange3](http://localhost:8088/images/Orange3.png)

msg.data:
USING A PYTHON DATA ANALYSIS SUITE WITH A GUI!

Orange3(http://orange.biolab.si/) is a nice opensource dataflow programming environment and library for working with data(needs Python 3.5 and above to work). You can install it using this command:

pip3 install -U orange3

Alternatively you could clone its source tree from Github.com and install it manually from https://github.com/biolab/orange3 .

To start using Orange3 run the following command in your terminal emulator or cmd:

orange-canvas
# or this command
python3 -m Orange.canvas
